abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment is of the
            Environmental Sewerage and Sanitation Project, which
            constructs a wastewater treatment plant (WWT) at Montagne
            Jacquot in Mauritius to improve sewage disposal and minimize
            industrial pollution. During project design, a buffer zone
            will be created around the WWT plant site perimeter to help
            reduce noise and offensive odors. If trees are planted in
            the buffer zone, potential odors carried inland by sporadic
            onshore breezes will also be further diminished. Noisy
            equipment will be enclosed. During construction, contractors
            will deploy silt curtains to minimize disturbance of
            sediments on the sea floor; locate and place anchors to
            avoid damage to the reef and massive corals; prevent and
            control discharges from vessels; contain waste fuel oil and
            retain garbage until properly disposed of onshore; provide
            emergency spill containment facilities; light construction
            vessels to ensure against collision with vessels in coastal
            waters; plan work hours to minimize nuisances and
            disturbance to the community; and plan trench digging to
            coincide with slack tide--or conditions which minimize
            deterioration in water quality. During operation, the plant
            manager will ensure that effluent quality is monitored daily
            and problems remedied as soon as possible; ensure that
            sludge is dewatered and regularly removed to the landfill;
            ensure rapid diagnosis and repair of industrial and
            wastewater leaks, spills, and blockages, and alert
            communities to health hazards.
